abstract.text: Select the optimal LAPACK routine to solve a system of linear equations.

metadata.title: Solving systems of linear equations with LAPACK

inlineContent.text: The Accelerate framework provides the LAPACK library for numerical linear algebra. A basic technique of linear algebra is to solve systems of simultaneous equations. For example, the following shows three equations that contain the unknowns
You can solve this system by rewriting the simultaneous equations as a matrix equation with the following form:
is a column vector that contains the unknown values, and
is a column vector that contains the constant values. The number of elements in
is equal to the number of columns of
, and the number of elements in
is equal to the number of rows of
The process of solving this system computes the values for
For an example of solving a linear system, see
LAPACK includes routines for solving systems of linear equations as
. This sample code project includes wrapper functions that simplify calling the LAPACK routines, for example, by encapsulating multiple-step workflows into a single function call.
Run the sample code app to see the results of each routine solve different example systems.

content.text: Determine the properties of the coefficient matrix

inlineContent.text: LAPACK provides different solving routines depending on the properties of the coefficient matrix,

? A symmetric matrix is one that’s equal to its transpose, that is, a matrix that’s identical when swapping its row and column indices. A symmetric matrix is necessarily square. The following is an example of a symmetric matrix:
? A matrix is positive definite if all of its
are positive. Confirm whether a matrix is positive definite by calling
. If the factorization fails and returns a positive value, the matrix isn’t positive definite. This sample code project includes the function
to determine whether a matrix is positive definite.

? A banded matrix has all of its nonzero entries on its main diagonal and an arbitrary number of superdiagonals (above the main diagonal) and subdiagonals (below the main diagonal). The following is an example of a nonsymmetric, banded matrix with two superdiagonals and one subdiagonal:
? A tridiagonal matrix has all of its nonzero entries on its main diagonal, its first superdiagonal, and its first subdiagonal. The following is an example of a nonsymmetric, tridiagonal matrix:
, that is, most of the entries in the coefficient matrix are zero, Accelerate provides the
library to help solve such systems.

content.text: Select LAPACK variants for data types

inlineContent.text: The LAPACK routines in this sample code project are all for real, single-precision matrices. All of the routines are available in single- and double-precision for real and complex values. The first character of a routine name defines the type of data the routine works on. For example:
For complex matrices, the LAPACK routine variant for real symmetric matrices requires
for a complex single-precision, Hermitian, tridiagonal coefficient matrix; and
computes the solution for a real single-precision, symmetric, tridiagonal coefficient matrix.
The routines in this sample code project are suitable for solving full rank systems, that is, they have a unique and exact solution.

The LAPACK routines in this article require the matrix data in column-major layout, which means specifying all the terms in the first column, then all of the terms in the second column, the third column, and so on. For example, if there are two columns with three row values each, the routine specifies the three row values for column one, then the three row values for column two, as the following example illustrates:
The routines return the result as column-major, for example, an array that contains

content.text: Select the solving routine for the coefficient matrix type

inlineContent.text: This sample code project provides Swift wrapper functions to each single-precision LAPACK solving routine. Select the routine that most closely matches the coefficient matrix for the highest performance. The following shows the Swift wrapper functions and the underlying LAPACK routines to solve systems with different coefficient matrices:

content.text: Solve for a nonsquare matrix using QR factorization

inlineContent.text: A system of linear equations with a nonsquare coefficient matrix is either:
Overdetermined — there are more equations than unknowns, that is, the coefficient matrix has more rows than columns. In this case, the system may not have a solution.
Underdetermined — there are more unknowns than equations, that is, the coefficient matrix has more columns than rows. In this case, the system may have infinitely many solutions.

In these cases, the solution is either not exact (unless the overdetermined system is actually consistent) or not unique. In the case where LAPACK is unable to solve the system, the Swift wrapper functions return
. This routine takes one of two approaches, depending on the system:
, has more rows than columns (overdetermined), the routine minimizes the error in
by solving the least squares problem
. The following image shows the graph of an overdetermined system with two unknowns and three equations.
, and the sum of the residuals squared (that is,
). Selecting any other point in the triangle of the three intercepts yields a larger sum of residuals squared.
, has more columns than rows (underdetermined), the routine finds the smallest
.  The following image shows the graph of
, which is the set of solutions to the illustrated system. The closest point on the line to the origin is at x = -0.5, y = 0.5.
The following is an example of an underdetermined system with a coefficient matrix that’s nonsquare:

code: /// Call `nonsymmetric_nonsquare` to compute the _x_ in _Ax = b_.
/// Prints _b_ in _Ax = b_ using the computed _x_: `~[355, 930, 1505]`.

inlineContent.text: Systems with a symmetric matrix that’s not full rank,
, don’t have a single unique solution. For example, the following two multiplications contain different
matrices, but yield the same result in
, returns an error indicating that the routine can’t compute the solution.

One option to deal with rank-deficiency is to instead solve a nearby problem of full rank by adding a small epsilon value to the matrix to regularize it. The following code adds such an epsilon to diagonal elements in matrix

code: /// Call `symmetric_indefinite_general` to compute the _x_ in _Ax = b_.
/// Prints _b_ in _Ax = b_ using the computed _x_: `~[80, 100, 80]`.

accelerate-solving-systems-linear-equati.alt: A line chart that contains three lines with the slope intercepts of y equals minus x plus 2, y equals 2 x minus 4, and y equals x plus 0. The three lines form a triangle and a marked point within the triangle represents the result of minimizing A x minus b.
A line chart that contains a single line with the slope intercept of y equals x plus 1, and a marked point that’s nearest to the chart origin.

b-matrix_2x.png.alt: Matrix that consists of three rows and two columns of numbers. The first column has the values 80, 180, and 160. The second column has the values 800, 1800, and 1600.

banded_2x.png.alt: Matrix that consists of five rows and five columns of numbers representing a nonsymmetric, banded matrix.

abstract.text: Make large-scale mathematical computations and image calculations, optimized for high performance and low energy consumption.
Perform common linear algebra operations with Apple’s implementation of the Basic Linear Algebra Subprograms (BLAS).
Reduce the storage size of an image using singular value decomposition (SVD).

doc://com.apple.accelerate/documentation.title: Compressing an image using linear algebra

abstract.text: Use LAPACK to solve a linear system and find an interpolating polynomial to construct new points between a series of known data points.

doc://com.apple.accelerate/documentation.title: Finding an interpolating polynomial using the Vandermonde method

abstract.text: Solve systems of equations where the coefficient matrix is sparse.

leastsquares-nonsquare_2x.png.alt: Mathematical formula that describes the matrix equation, A x equals b. A four-by-three matrix multiplied by a three-element column matrix equals a four-element column matrix.

nonsymmetric-nonsquare_2x.png.alt: Mathematical formula that describes the matrix equation, A x equals b. A three-by-five matrix multiplied by a five-element column matrix equals a three-element column matrix.

overdetermined_graph_2x.png.alt: A series of equations that show the slope intercepts as A x equals b with the constants on the right.

simulataneous-ax=b_2x.png.alt: Mathematical formula that describes the matrix equation, A x equals b. A three-by-three matrix multiplied by a three-element column matrix equals a three-element column matrix.

simultaneous-solution_2x.png.alt: Mathematical formula that describes the matrix equation, A x equals b with the computed unknowns on the left, and the same system as a set of simultaneous equations on the right.

symmetric-indefinite-general-2_2x.png.alt: Mathematical formula that describes the matrix equation, A x equals b. A three-by-three matrix multiplied by a three-element column matrix equals a three-element column matrix.

symmetric-indefinite-general_2x.png.alt: Two stacked mathematical formulas that describe the matrix equation, A x equals b. Each formula is a three-by-three matrix multiplied by a three-element column matrix that equals a three-element column matrix. In both cases, matrices A and b contain the same values, but matrix x has different values.

symmetric_2x.png.alt: Matrix that consists of five rows and five columns of numbers. The numbers in the first row are the same as those in the first column. The numbers in the second row are the same as in the second column, and so forth.

tridiagonal_2x.png.alt: Matrix that consists of five rows and five columns of numbers representing a nonsymmetric, tridiagonal matrix.

underdetermined_graph_2x.png.alt: A series of equations that show the slope intercept as A x equals b with the constants on the right.

x-matrix_2x.png.alt: Matrix that consists of three rows and two columns of numbers. The first column has the values 10, 20, and 30. The second column has the values 100, 200, and 300.
